questions.title: I
questions.article:
Some students conducted 4 studies using slidewire generators of various sizes. Each slidewire generator contained a U-shaped electrical conductor (USEC), a movable conducting rod of length L that connected the sides of the USEC, and an ammeter (A). All conductors were made of the same metal. Using a motor-driven shaft attached to the conducting rod, the students could move the rod either to the left or to the right at speed v (see Figure 1).


In each trial, the slidewire generator was placed perpendicular to a magnetic field of strength B that pointed vertically toward the ceiling. The field was constant in strength and direction. When the rod was moved, amount an of electrical current, I, was generated in the circuit made by the USEC and the conducting rod (see Figure 2).


I was positive when the current moved clockwise through the circuit and negative when the current moved counter-clockwise through the circuit.


Study 1
The students moved a rod of length L = 0.20 m to the right at various v and measured I in milliamps (mA) for each v (see Table 1). B was the same across the 3 trials.



Study 2
The students moved rods of various L to the right at v = 0.20m/sec and found I for each rod (see Table 2). For each trial, B = 0.40 tesla (T).


Study 3
The students moved a rod of L = 0.20 m to the right at v = 0.20m/sec in fields of various B and found I for each B (see Table 3).


Study 4
The students moved a rod of L = 0.20 m to the left at various v and found I for each v (see Table 4). In each trial, B was the same as in Study 1.
questions.question: 1. In Study 1, I would most likely have equaled +8.0 mA if v had been:

questions.question: 2. In Study 2, as the length of the conducting rod increased, the amount of electrical current through the loop:

choices.D: varied, but with no general trend.

questions.title: II
questions.article:
The order Anura includes frogs and toads. Table 1 is a key for identifying some anurans in national forests in California.


Tables 2 describes 4 anurans that were seen in national forests in California.

questions.title: III
questions.article:
A mercury thermometer, at an initial temperature of 20°C, was placed in 30°C water, and the temperature registered by the thermometer was recorded over time. This procedure was repeated using water samples at 40°C and 50°C (see Figure 1). Next, the same thermometer, at an initial temperature of 50°C, was placed in an air sample at 20°C, and the temperature registered by the thermometer was recorded over time. This procedure was repeated using air samples at 30℃ and 40℃ (see Figure 2).

(Note: Assume that the designated temperatures of the water samples and air samples did not change during the measurements.)
questions.question: 12. Based on Figure 2, at 250 sec, the thermometer reading in the 40℃ air most likely was closest to which of the following?

questions.title: III
questions.article:
A mercury thermometer, at an initial temperature of 20°C, was placed in 30°C water, and the temperature registered by the thermometer was recorded over time. This procedure was repeated using water samples at 40°C and 50°C (see Figure 1). Next, the same thermometer, at an initial temperature of 50°C, was placed in an air sample at 20°C, and the temperature registered by the thermometer was recorded over time. This procedure was repeated using air samples at 30℃ and 40℃ (see Figure 2).

(Note: Assume that the designated temperatures of the water samples and air samples did not change during the measurements.)
questions.question: 13. When the thermometer was in the 50℃ water, in the time interval between 2 sec and 3 sec, approximately how rapidly, in℃/sec, was the temperature registered by the thermometer changing?

questions.question: 14. According to Figure 2, for an air temperature of 20℃, over which of the following time intervals was the thermometer reading changing most rapidly?

questions.question: 15. Based on Figure 2, for the thermometer placed in 30℃ air, the average kinetic energy of the mercury atoms in the thermometer was greatest at which of the following times?

questions.question: 16. Based on Figure 2, if the thermometer, at an initial temperature of 50℃, had been placed in an air sample at 10℃, how long would it most likely have taken the thermometer reading to reach 10℃?

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
Amylase is an enzyme that speeds up the breakdown of starch into smaller carbohydrates (such as maltose).

A starch solution, an amylase solution, and several buffer solutions (solutions that maintain a constant pH) were prepared. Two experiments were done using these solutions and the following tests:

Iodine test: 3 drops of a brown KI3 solution is added to a sample solution. If starch is present in the sample solution, the solution will turn from brown to black.

Benedict's test: 1 mL of a blue solution containing CuSO4 is added to a sample solution. The solution is then heated in a boiling water bath for 3 min. If maltose present in the sample solution, the solution will turn is from blue to orange.

Experiment 1
Each of 7 test tubes was filled with 5 mL of pH 7.0 buffer solution. Different amounts of starch solution and/or amylase solution were added to each tube. The solution in each tube was then diluted to 10 mL with the buffer solution (so the final pH was 7.0 in each tube). Each tube was then incubated at a constant temperature for 10 min. The iodine and Benedict's tests were then each done with 2 mL samples drawn from each tube (see Table 1).


Experiment 2
Seven test tubes were filled and tested according to the procedure used for Tube 3, except that for each tube, a different buffer solution was used (see Table 2).
questions.question: 17. Based on the passage, amylase in humans is most directly associated with which of the following systems?

questions.article:

The iodine and Benedict's tests were then each done with 2 mL samples drawn from each tube (see Table 1).


Experiment 2
Seven test tubes were filled and tested according to the procedure used for Tube 3, except that for each tube, a different buffer solution was used (see Table 2).
questions.question: 18. Suppose an additional trial had been done in Experiment 2 using a buffer solution with a pH of 7.3. What would be the most likely results of the iodine and Benedict's tests?

choices.A: Iodine test: brown;      Benedict's test: blue
choices.B: Iodine test: brown;      Benedict's test: orange
choices.C: Iodine test: black;      Benedict's test: blue
choices.D: Iodine test: black;      Benedict's test: orange

questions.question: 22. Which of the following best describes the relationship between the starch concentration and the maltose concentration during the incubation of Tube 3? As the starch concentration:

choices.B: decreased, the maltose concentration remained constant.
choices.D: increased, the maltose concentration remained constant.

questions.title: V
questions.article: Students studied the photodecomposition (breakdown by light) of p-nitrophenol (a toxic pollutant) in wastewater. They measured the concentration of p-nitrophenol (in parts per million, ppm) in wastewater samples during exposure to various lighting conditions. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) and/or hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were added to some samples at the start of exposure (time = 0 min). TiO2 and H2O2 speed up some photodecomposition reactions. The results of 3 sets of experiments are shown in Figures 1-3.
questions.question: 23. According to Figure 1, 60 min after TiO2, was added to the wastewater sample that was NOT exposed to sunlight, the concentration of p-nitrophenol was closest to which of the following?

questions.title: V

The results of 3 sets of experiments are shown in Figures 1-3.
questions.question: 24. According to Figure 1, for the sample that contained TiO2, and was exposed to sunlight, the greatest amount of p-nitrophenol decomposed during which of the following time intervals?

questions.question: 25. For which of the 3 figures did all of the wastewater samples studied have the same initial p-nitrophenol concentration?

questions.question: 26. Based on the information in the passage, which of the following best describes and explains the results shown in Figure 2? As time increased from 0 min to 180 min, the concentration of p-nitrophenol in the 3 samples:

choices.A: decreased, because the p-nitrophenol changed from a liquid to a gas.
choices.B: decreased, because the p-nitrophenol molecules broke down to form other substances.
choices.C: increased, because the p-nitrophenol changed from a liquid to a gas.
choices.D: increased, because the p-nitrophenol molecules broke down to form other substances.

questions.title: V
questions.article: Students studied the photodecomposition (breakdown by light) of p-nitrophenol (a toxic pollutant) in wastewater. They measured the concentration of p-nitrophenol (in parts per million, ppm) in wastewater samples during exposure to various lighting conditions. Titanium dioxide (TiO2) and/or hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) were added to some samples at the start of exposure (time = 0 min). TiO2 and H2O2 speed up some photodecomposition reactions. The results of 3 sets of experiments are shown in Figures 1-3.
questions.question: 27. A chemist claimed that adding H2O2 to wastewater containing p-nitrophenol will cause the p-nitrophenol to decompose in the absence of light. Do the results from any of the figures confirm her claim?

choices.A: Yes; according to Figure 1, the p-nitrophenol concentration only decreased in the sample containing H2O2, tested in the absence of light.
choices.B: Yes; according to Figure 3, the p-nitrophenol concentration only decreased in the sample containing H2O2.
choices.C: No; according to Figure 1, the p-nitrophenol concentration only decreased in the sample containing H2O2 tested in the absence of light.
choices.D: No; according to Figures 1-3, no samples containing H2O2 were tested in the absence of light.

questions.title: VI
questions.article:
Water flowing over the sediment in a river channel creates bedforms (3-dimensional structures formed in the sediment). The processes that produce bedforms in presentday river channels produced the same types of bedforms in ancient river channels. Ancient bedforms are often found preserved in sedimentary rock layers. Figure 1 shows a longitudinal cross section of 3 types of bedforms: ripples, dunes, and flat beds.


A geologist conducted 3 studies using an artificial river channel 15 m long, 1 m wide, and 0.6 m deep.Water velocity through the channel and water flow depth could be controlled. At the start of each study, a flat, 15 cm thick layer of sand particles of uniform diameter was placed in the bottom of the channel. Various combinations of water velocity, from 0.2 m/sec to 2.0 m/sec, and of water flow depth, from 0.1 m to 0.4 m, were tested in each of the 3 studies.

Study 1
The bottom of the channel was covered with fine sand particles, all having a diameter of 0.19 mm. Water was passed over the sediment bed. The resulting bedform stability fields (water velocities and water flow depths at which various types of bedforms were present) are shown in Figure 2.



Study 2
Study 1 was repeated using medium sand particles, all having a diameter of 0.45 mm.The resulting bedform stability fields are shown in Figure 3.



Study 3
Study 1 was repeated using coarse sand particles, all having a diameter of 0.93 mm.The resulting bedform stability fields are shown in Figure 4.
questions.question: 28. Which of the following factors was NOT directly controlled by the geologist during the studies?

questions.title: VI
questions.article:
Water flowing over the sediment in a river channel creates bedforms (3-dimensional structures formed in the sediment). The processes that produce bedforms in presentday river channels produced the same types of bedforms in ancient river channels. Ancient bedforms are often found preserved in sedimentary rock layers. Figure 1 shows a longitudinal cross section of 3 types of bedforms: ripples, dunes, and flat beds.


A geologist conducted 3 studies using an artificial river channel 15 m long, 1 m wide, and 0.6 m deep.Water velocity through the channel and water flow depth could be controlled. At the start of each study, a flat, 15 cm thick layer of sand particles of uniform diameter was placed in the bottom of the channel. Various combinations of water velocity, from 0.2 m/sec to 2.0 m/sec, and of water flow depth, from 0.1 m to 0.4 m, were tested in each of the 3 studies.

Study 1
The bottom of the channel was covered with fine sand particles, all having a diameter of 0.19 mm. Water was passed over the sediment bed. The resulting bedform stability fields (water velocities and water flow depths at which various types of bedforms were present) are shown in Figure 2.



Study 2
Study 1 was repeated using medium sand particles, all having a diameter of 0.45 mm.The resulting bedform stability fields are shown in Figure 3.



Study 3
Study 1 was repeated using coarse sand particles, all having a diameter of 0.93 mm.The resulting bedform stability fields are shown in Figure 4.
questions.question: 29. Suppose Study 1 were repeated using sand particles all having a diameter of 0.30 mm.The resulting bedform stability fields would include which of the 3 types of bedforms referred to in the passage?

Study 1 was repeated using coarse sand particles, all having a diameter of 0.93 mm.The resulting bedform stability fields are shown in Figure 4.
questions.question: 30. A sedimentary rock layer containing preserved ripples was composed entirely of sediment particles with diameters between 0.4 mm and 0.5 mm. The water flow depth in the river at the time the ripples were forming was between 0.1 m and 0.4 m. Based on the information presented, the velocity of the river water was most likely:

questions.article:

questions.question: 31. According to the results of Studies 1 and 2, which of the following statements comparing the maximum water velocity at which ripples were present and the maximum water velocity at which dunes were present is true?

choices.A: For all water flow depths, the maximum water velocity at which ripples were present was higher than the corresponding maximum water velocity at which dunes were present.
choices.B: For all water flow depths, the maximum water velocity at which ripples were present was lower than the corresponding maximum water velocity at which dunes were present.
choices.C: For only some of the water flow depths, the maximum water velocity at which ripples were present was higher than the corresponding maximum water velocity at which dunes were present.
choices.D: For only some of the water flow depths, the maximum water velocity at which ripples were present was lower than the corresponding maximum water velocity at which dunes were present.

questions.question: 32. According to the results of Study 3, for a given water velocity, as the water flow depth increased, the type of bedform present:

choices.B: changed from dunes to flat beds.
choices.C: changed from flat beds to dunes.

questions.question: 33. Consider the average wavelength of a ripple bedform and the average wavelength of a dune bedform, as shown in Figure 1. Which, if either, is(are)greater than 10 cm?

choices.A: The average wavelength of a ripple bedform only
choices.B: The average wavelength of a dune bedform only
choices.C: Both the average wavelength of a ripple bedform and the average wavelength of a dune bedform
choices.D: Neither the average wavelength of a ripple bedform nor the average wavelength of a dune bedform

questions.title: VII
questions.article:
Vapor pressure is the pressure exerted by the vapor above a liquid in a closed container at a given temperature and at equilibrium. At equilibrium, the rate of evaporation equals the rate of condensation.

Two students observed that the vapor pressure of H2O decreased when NaCl was dissolved in the H2O. The students then offered explanations for why this decrease occurred.

Student 1
Solvent molecules are attracted to charged solute particles. This causes solvent molecules to surround solute particles, forming clusters. Additional energy is needed to break solvent molecules free from these clusters. Thus, at a given temperature, the vapor pressure of the solution is lower than that of the pure liquid. The vapor pressure decreases as the concentration of charged solute particles increases and as the magnitude of the charge on each solute particle increases. Neutral solute particles do not affect the vapor pressure of a liquid.

Student 2
Vapor pressure decreases because some of the solvent particles that have sufficient energy to escape the solution's surface collide with the solute particles and lose energy. Thus, at a given temperature, the vapor pressure of the solution is lower than that of the pure liquid. The size of the decrease in vapor pressure is directly proportional to the concentration of solute particles.A neutral solute particle decreases the vapor pressure of a liquid by the same amount as does a charged solute particle.The concentration of solute particles is the only factor that affects the vapor pressure of a liquid.

Experiment
Three 1 kg solutions were made by dissolving 1.0 mole (6 × 1023 units or molecules) of glucose, NaCl, or CaCl2, respectively, in distilled H2O. Thus, the concentration of each solution was 1.0 mole/kg. Table 1 shows the solute particle(s) resulting from each unit (or molecule) of each substance dissolved in H2O. The students then measured the vapor pressure of distilled H2O and of each solution at 25℃.
questions.question: 34. Which of the following diagrams best illustrates how Student 1 would describe the change that occurs when NaCl is dissolved in H2O ?

questions.question: 35. Do the 2 students differ in their descriptions of how solvent molecules interact with solute particles in a solution?

choices.A: Yes; Student 1 claims solvent molecules are attracted to charged solute particles and Student 2 does not.
choices.B: Yes; Student 2 claims solvent molecules are attracted to charged solute particles and Student 1 does not.
choices.C: No; both students claim that the solvent molecules surround charged solute particles.
choices.D: No; neither student discusses the interactions of solvent molecules with solute particles.

questions.question: 36. Based on Table 1, how did the concentration of solute particles in Solution 3 compare to the concentration of particles in Solution 1? The concentration of solute solute particles in Solution 3 was:

choices.A: lower, because each CaCl2 unit dissolves into fewer solute particles than does each glucose molecule.
choices.B: lower, because each CaCl2 unit dissolves into more solute particles than does each glucose molecule.
choices.C: higher, because each CaCl2 unit dissolves into fewer solute particles than does each glucose molecule.
choices.D: higher, because each CaCl2 unit dissolves into more solute particles than does each glucose molecule.

questions.question: 37. Suppose an experiment showed that each Na  in a saltwater solution exists in a cluster with 3 H2O molecules. This finding would support the explanation(s) of which of the students, if either?

questions.question: 38. When table sugar is dissolved in pure H2O at 25℃, the vapor pressure at equilibrium is lower than that of pure H2O at 25℃. Because dissolved table sugar molecules are neutral, this observation contradicts the explanation of:

choices.A: Student 1, because Student 1 claims that only charged solute particles can cause the vapor pressure to decrease.
choices.B: Student 2, because Student 2 claims that only charged solute particles can cause the vapor pressure to decrease.
choices.C: Student 1, because Student l claims that only uncharged solute particles can cause the vapor pressure to decrease.
choices.D: Student 2, because Student 2 claims that only uncharged solute particles can cause the vapor pressure to decrease.

questions.question: 39. With which of the following statements about solutes would both students agree? Adding to a liquid a substance that dissolves:

choices.A: and dissociates into ions will decrease the liquid's vapor pressure.
choices.B: and dissociates into ions will increase the liquid's vapor pressure.
choices.C: but does not dissociate into ions will decrease the liquid's vapor pressure.
choices.D: but does not dissociate into ions will increase the liquid's vapor pressure.

questions.question: 40. Assume the following for the addition of a substance to a pure liquid:△P = the decrease in vapor pressure    C = the concentration of solute particles     k = a constant Which of the following equations is most consistent with Student 2's explanation?
